==Self-healing polymers and elastomers== In the last century, polymers became a base material in everyday life for products like plastics, rubbers, films, fibres or paints. This huge demand has forced to extend their reliability and maximum lifetime, and a new design class of polymeric materials that are able to restore their functionality after damage or fatigue was envisaged. These polymer materials can be divided into two different groups based on the approach to the self-healing mechanism: intrinsic or extrinsic.<ref name=Yang>{{cite journal|last1=Yang|first1=Y.|last2=Urban|first2=M. W.|title=Self-healing polymeric materials|journal=Chemical Society Reviews|date=2013|volume=42|issue=17|pages=7446–7467|doi=10.1039/c3cs60109a|pmid=23864042}}</ref> Autonomous self-healing [[polymer]]s follow a three-step process very similar to that of a biological response. In the event of damage, the first response is triggering or actuation, which happens almost immediately after damage is sustained. The second response is transport of materials to the effected area, which also happens very quickly. The third response is the chemical repair process. This process differs depending on the type of healing mechanism that is in place (e.g., [[polymerization]], entanglement, reversible cross-linking). These self-healing materials can be classified in three different ways: capsule based, vascular, and intrinsic. While similar in some ways, these three ways differ in the ways that response is hidden or prevented until actual damage is sustained.
===Polymer breakdown=== From a molecular perspective, traditional polymers yield to mechanical stress through cleavage of [[sigma bond]]s.<ref name=chemreview>{{cite journal|title = Mechanically-Induced Chemical Changes in Polymeric Materials|journal = Chem. Rev.|year = 2009|volume=109|issue = 11|pmid = 19827748|pages=5755–5758|doi = 10.1021/cr9001353|author = Caruso, M. |last2 = Davis|first2 = Douglas A.|last3 = Shen|first3 = Qilong|last4 = Odom|first4 = Susan A.|last5 = Sottos|first5 = Nancy R.|last6 = White|first6 = Scott R.|last7 = Moore|first7 = Jeffrey S.}}</ref> While newer polymers can yield in other ways, traditional polymers typically yield through [[homolysis bond cleavage|homolytic]] or [[heterolytic bond cleavage]]. The factors that determine how a polymer will yield include: type of stress, chemical properties inherent to the polymer, level and type of [[solvation]], and temperature.<ref name="chemreview"/> From a [[macromolecular]] perspective, stress induced damage at the molecular level leads to larger scale damage called microcracks.<ref name=jrs>{{cite journal|title = Self-healing of damage in fibre-reinforced polymer-matrix composites|journal = Journal of the Royal Society|year = 2007|volume =4|issue = 13|pmid = 17311783|pages =381–387|pmc = 2359850|doi = 10.1098/rsif.2006.0209|author = Jones, F.R.|last2 = Zhang|first2 = W.|last3 = Branthwaite|first3 = M.|last4 = Jones|first4 = F.R.}}</ref> A microcrack is formed where neighboring polymer chains have been damaged in close proximity, ultimately leading to the weakening of the fiber as a whole.<ref name="jrs"/>
====Homolytic bond cleavage==== [[File:HomolyticcleavageofPMMA.gif|thumb|300 px|'''Scheme 1.''' Homolytic cleavage of [[poly(methyl methacrylate)]] (PMMA).]] Polymers have been observed to undergo homolytic bond cleavage through the use of [[Radical (chemistry)|radical]] reporters such as [[DPPH]] (2,2-diphenyl-1-picrylhydrazyl) and PMNB (pentamethylnitrosobenzene.) When a bond is cleaved homolytically, two radical species are formed which can recombine to repair damage or can initiate other homolytic cleavages which can in turn lead to more damage.<ref name="chemreview"/>
====Heterolytic bond cleavage==== [[File:HeterolyticcleavageofPEG.gif|thumb|300 px|'''Scheme 2.''' Heterolytic cleavage of [[polyethylene glycol]].]] Polymers have also been observed to undergo heterolytic bond cleavage through isotope labeling experiments. When a bond is cleaved heterolytically, [[cationic]] and [[anionic]] species are formed which can in turn recombine to repair damage, can be [[quenched]] by solvent, or can react destructively with nearby polymers.<ref name="chemreview"/>
====Reversible bond cleavage==== Certain polymers yield to mechanical stress in an atypical, reversible manner.<ref name=mendablepolymers>{{cite journal|title = Mendable Polymers|journal = [[Journal of Materials Chemistry]]|year = 2008|volume =18|pages =41–62|doi = 10.1039/b713953p|author1 = Bergman, S.D.|author2 = Wudl, F.}}</ref> [[Diels-Alder]]-based polymers undergo a reversible [[cycloaddition]], where mechanical stress cleaves two [[sigma bond]]s in a retro [[Diels-Alder]] reaction. This stress results in additional pi-bonded electrons as opposed to radical or charged moieties.<ref name=polylett>{{cite journal|title = Self healing in polymers and polymer composites. Concepts, realization and outlook: A review|journal = Polymer Letters|year = 2008|volume =2|pages =238–250|doi = 10.3144/expresspolymlett.2008.29|author = Zang, M.Q.|issue = 4}}</ref>
====Supramolecular breakdown==== [[Supramolecular]] [[polymer]]s are composed of monomers that interact [[non-covalent]]ly.<ref name=JMS>{{cite journal|title = Hydrogen-bonded supramolecules polymers: A literature review|journal = [[Journal of Materials Science]]|first2 = M.|year = 2005|last2 = Buggy|volume= 40|pages =547–559|doi = 10.1007/s10853-005-6288-7|author = Armstrong, G.|issue = 3|bibcode = 2005JMatS..40..547A }}</ref> Common interactions include [[hydrogen bond]]s, metal [[Coordination complex|coordination]], and [[van der Waals forces]].<ref name="JMS"/> Mechanical stress in supramolecular polymers causes the disruption of these specific non-covalent interactions, leading to monomer separation and polymer breakdown.
===Intrinsic polymer-based systems=== In intrinsic systems, the material is inherently able to restore its integrity. While extrinsic approaches are generally autonomous, intrinsic systems often require an external trigger for the healing to take place (such as thermo-mechanical, electrical, photo-stimuli, etc.). It is possible to distinguish among 5 main intrinsic self-healing strategies. The first one is based on reversible reactions, and the most widely used reaction scheme is based on Diels-Alder (DA) and retro-Diels-Alder (rDA) reactions.<ref name=dendrimer/> Another strategy achieves the self-healing in thermoset matrices by incorporating meltable thermoplastic additives. A temperature trigger allows the redispertion of thermoplastic additives into cracks, giving rise to mechanical interlocking.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Luo|first1=X.|last2=Ou|first2=R.|last3=Eberly|first3=D.E.|last4=Singhal|first4=A.|last5=Viratyaporn|first5=W.|last6=Mather|first6=P.T.|title=A Thermoplastic/Thermoset Blend Exhibiting Thermal Mending and Reversible Adhesion|journal=ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces|date=2009|volume=1|issue=3|pages=612–620|doi=10.1021/am8001605|pmid=20355983}}</ref> Polymer interlockings based on dynamic supramolecular bonds or ionomers represent a third and fourth scheme. The involved supramolecular interactions and ionomeric clusters are generally reversible and act as reversible cross-links, thus can equip polymers with self-healing ability.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Cordier|first1=P.|last2=Tournilhac|first2=F.|last3=Soulié-Ziakovic|first3=C.|last4=Leibler|first4=L|title=Self-healing and thermoreversible rubber from supramolecular assembly|journal=Nature|date=2008|volume=451|issue=7181|pages=977–980|doi=10.1038/nature06669|pmid=18288191|bibcode=2008Natur.451..977C}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Kalista|first1=S.J.|last2=Ward|first2=T.C.|last3=Oyetunji|first3=Z.|title=Self-Healing of Poly(Ethylene-co-Methacrylic Acid) Copolymers Following Projectile Puncture|journal=Mechanics of Advanced Materials and Structures|date=2007|volume=14|issue=5|pages=391–97|doi=10.1080/15376490701298819}}</ref> Finally, an alternative method for achieving intrinsic self-healing is based on molecular diffusion.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Yamaguchi|first1=M.|last2=Ono|first2=S.|last3=Okamoto|first3=K.|title=Interdiffusion of dangling chains in weak gel and its application to self-repairing material|journal=Mater. Sci. Eng. B|date=2009|volume=162|issue=3|pages=189–94|doi=10.1016/j.mseb.2009.04.006}}</ref>
====Reversible bond-based polymers==== Reversible systems are polymeric systems that can revert to the initial state whether it is [[monomeric]], [[oligomeric]], or non-cross-linked. Since the [[polymer]] is stable under normal condition, the reversible process usually requires an external stimulus for it to occur. For a reversible healing polymer, if the material is damaged by means such as heating and reverted to its constituents, it can be repaired or "healed" to its [[polymer]] form by applying the original condition used to polymerize it.
====Polymer systems based on covalent bond formation and breakage ====
=====Diels-Alder and retro-Diels-Alder===== Among the examples of reversible healing polymers, the [[Diels-Alder]] (DA) reaction and its retro-[[Diels-Alder]] (RDA) analogue seems to be very promising due to its thermal reversibility. In general, the [[monomer]] containing the functional groups such as [[furan]] or [[maleimide]] form two carbon-carbon bonds in a specific manner and construct the polymer through DA reaction. This polymer, upon heating, breaks down to its original monomeric units via RDA reaction and then reforms the [[polymer]] upon cooling or through any other conditions that were initially used to make the polymer. During the last few decades, two types of reversible [[polymer]]s have been studied: (i) polymers where the pendant groups, such as [[furan]] or [[maleimide]] groups, cross-link through successive DA coupling reactions; (ii) polymers where the multifunctional monomers link to each other through successive DA coupling reactions.<ref name=mendablepolymers />
======Cross-linked polymers====== In this type of [[polymer]], the polymer forms through the cross linking of the pendant groups from the linear [[thermoplastics]]. For example, Saegusa ''et al.'' have shown the reversible cross-linking of modified poly(''N''-acetylethyleneimine)s containing either [[maleimide]] or furancarbonyl pendant moideties. The reaction is shown in Scheme 3. They mixed the two complementary [[polymer]]s to make a highly [[cross-linked]] material through DA reaction of furan and maleimide units at room temperature, as the [[cross-linked]] [[polymer]] is more thermodynamically stable than the individual starting materials. However, upon heating the polymer to 80 °C for two hours in a [[Chemical polarity|polar]] [[solvent]], two [[monomer]]s were regenerated via RDA reaction, indicating the breaking of [[polymer]]s.<ref name=macromolecules>{{cite journal|title = Reversible Gelation of Polyoxazoline by Means of Diels-Alder Reaction|journal = Macromolecules|year = 1990|volume =23|pages=2636–2641|doi = 10.1021/ma00212a007|author1 = Chujo, Y.|author2 = Sada, K.|author3 = Saegusa, T.|issue = 10|bibcode = 1990MaMol..23.2636C }}</ref> This was possible because the heating energy provided enough energy to go over the energy barrier and results in the two [[monomer]]s. Cooling the two starting [[monomer]]s, or damaged [[polymer]], to room temperature for 7 days healed and reformed the polymer. [[File:Cross-linking DA.png| thumb|600 px| center|'''Scheme 3.''' Reversible polymer cross-linking via [[Diels-Alder]] [[cycloaddition]] reaction between furan and maleimide.<ref name=macromolecules />]] The reversible DA/RDA reaction is not limited to furan-meleimides based [[polymer]]s as it is shown by the work of Schiraldi ''et al.'' They have shown the reversible cross-linking of polymers bearing pendent [[anthracene]] group with maleimides. However, the reversible reaction occurred only partially upon heating to 250 °C due to the competing [[decomposition]] reaction.<ref name=Jones>{{cite journal|title = Cross-Linking and Modification of Poly(ethylene terephthalate-co-2,6-anthracenedicarboxylate) by Diels−Alder Reactions with Maleimides|journal = Macromolecules|year = 1999|volume =32|pages =5786–5792|doi = 10.1021/ma990638z|author = Schiraldi, D.A|last2 = Liotta|first2 = Charles L.|last3 = Collard|first3 = David M.|last4 = Schiraldi|first4 = David A.|issue = 18|bibcode = 1999MaMol..32.5786J }}</ref>
======Polymerization of multifunctional monomers====== In these systems, the DA reaction takes place in the backbone itself to construct the polymer, not as a link. For polymerization and healing processes of a DA-step-growth [[furan]]-[[maleimide]] based polymer (3M4F) were demonstrated by subjecting it to heating/cooling cycles. Tris-maleimide (3M) and tetra-furan (4F) formed a polymer through DA reaction and, when heated to 120 °C, de-polymerized through RDA reaction, resulting in the starting materials. Subsequent heating to 90–120 °C and cooling to room temperature healed the polymer, partially restoring its mechanical properties through intervention.<ref name=dendrimer>{{cite journal|title = A Thermally Re-mendable Cross-Linked Polymeric Material|journal = Science|year = 2002|volume =295|pages =1698–1702|doi = 10.1126/science.1065879|author = Chen, X.|pmid = 11872836|last2 = Dam|first2 = MA|last3 = Ono|first3 = K|last4 = Mal|first4 = A|last5 = Shen|first5 = H|last6 = Nutt|first6 = SR|last7 = Sheran|first7 = K|last8 = Wudl|first8 = F|issue = 5560|bibcode = 2002Sci...295.1698C }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=Synthesis of a Self-Healing Polymer Based on Reversible Diels–Alder Reaction: An Advanced Undergraduate Laboratory at the Interface of Organic Chemistry and Materials Science|doi=10.1021/ed101109f|year=2011|last1=Weizman|first1=Haim|last2=Nielsen|first2=Christian|last3=Weizman|first3=Or S.|last4=Nemat-Nasser|first4=Sia|journal=Journal of Chemical Education|volume=88|issue=8|pages=1137–1140|bibcode=2011JChEd..88.1137W}}</ref> The reaction is shown in Scheme 4. [[File:DAstepgrowthpolymer.png|thumb|400 px| center|'''Scheme 4.''' Reversible highly cross-linked furan-maleimide based polymer network.<ref name=dendrimer />]]
=====Thiol-based polymers===== The thiol-based polymers have [[disulfide bonds]] that can be reversibly cross-linked through [[oxidation]] and [[redox|reduction]]. Under reducing condition, the [[disulfide]] (SS) bridges in the polymer breaks and results in monomers, however, under oxidizing condition, the [[thiols]] (SH) of each monomer forms the [[disulfide bond]], cross-linking the starting materials to form the polymer. Chujo ''et al.'' have shown the [[thiol]]-based reversible cross-linked polymer using poly(''N''-acetylethyleneimine). (Scheme 5) <ref name=disulfidebridge>{{cite journal|title = Synthesis and redox gelation of disulfide-modified polyoxazoline|journal = Macromolecules|year = 1993|volume =26|pages =883–887|doi = 10.1021/ma00057a001|author = Saegusa, T.|last2 = Sada|first2 = Kazuki|last3 = Naka|first3 = Akio|last4 = Nomura|first4 = Ryoji|last5 = Saegusa|first5 = Takeo|issue = 5|bibcode = 1993MaMol..26..883C }}</ref> [[File:Disulfidebridge.png|thumb|500 px|center|'''Scheme 5.''' Reversible polymer cross-linking by disulfide bridges.<ref name=disulfidebridge />]]
=====Poly(urea-urethane)===== A soft poly(urea-urethane) network uses the metathesis reaction in aromatic disulphides to provide room-temperature self-healing properties, without the need for external catalysts. This chemical reaction is naturally able to create covalent bonds at room temperature, allowing the polymer to autonomously heal without an external source of energy. Left to rest at room temperature, the material mended itself with 80 percent efficiency after only two hours and 97 percent after 24 hours.{{citation needed|date=February 2014}} In 2014 a polyurea [[elastomer]]-based material was shown to be self-healing, melding together after being cut in half, without the addition of catalysts or other chemicals. The material also include inexpensive commercially available compounds. The elastomer molecules were tweaked, making the bonds between them longer. The resulting molecules are easier to pull apart from one another and better able to rebond at room temperature with almost the same strength. The rebonding can be repeated. Stretchy, self-healing paints and other coatings recently took a step closer to common use, thanks to research being conducted at the University of Illinois. Scientists there have used "off-the-shelf" components to create a polymer that melds back together after being cut in half, without the addition of catalysts or other chemicals.<ref>{{cite web|first=Richard |last=Green|url=http://www.gizmag.com/dynamic-polyurea-self-healing-polymer/30750 |title=Scientists create an inexpensive self-healing polymer |publisher=Gizmag.com |date=2014-02-15|accessdate=2014-02-26}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1038/ncomms4218| pmid = 24492620| pmc = 4438999| title = Dynamic urea bond for the design of reversible and self-healing polymers| journal = Nature Communications| volume = 5| pages = 3218| year = 2014| last1 = Ying | first1 = H. | last2 = Zhang | first2 = Y. | last3 = Cheng | first3 = J. | bibcode = 2014NatCo...5E3218Y}}</ref>
The urea-urethane polymers however have glassy transition temperatures below 273 K therefore at room temperature they are gels and their tensile strength is low.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ying|first=Hanze|last2=Zhang|first2=Yanfeng|last3=Cheng|first3=Jianjun|date=2014|title=Dynamic urea bond for the design of reversible and self-healing polymers|journal=Nature Communications|volume=5|pages=3218|doi=10.1038/ncomms4218|issn=2041-1723|pmc=4438999|pmid=24492620|bibcode=2014NatCo...5E3218Y}}</ref> To optimize the tensile strength the reversible bonding energy, or the polymer length must be increased to increase the degree of covalent or mechanical interlocking respectively. However, increase polymer length inhibits mobility and thereby impairs the ability for polymers to re-reversibly bond. Thus at each polymer length an optimal reversible bonding energy exists.<ref>{{Cite journal|date=2017-03-14|title=Molecular dynamics of reversible self-healing materials|url=http://meetings.aps.org/Meeting/MAR17/Session/H18.2|journal=Bulletin of the American Physical Society|volume= 62| issue = 4}}</ref>
===Extrinsic polymer-based systems === In extrinsic systems, the healing chemistries are separated from the surrounding polymer in microcapsules or vascular networks, which after material damage/cracking release their content into the crack plane, reacting and allowing the restoration of material functionalities.<ref name="BlaiszikKramer2010"/> These systems can be further subdivided in several categories. While capsule-based polymers sequester the healing agents in little capsules that only release the agents if they are ruptured, vascular self-healing materials sequester the healing agent in capillary type hollow channels which can be interconnected one dimensionally, two dimensionally, or three dimensionally. After one of these capillaries is damaged, the network can be refilled by an outside source or another channel that was not damaged. Intrinsic self-healing materials do not have a sequestered healing agent but instead have a latent self-healing functionality that is triggered by damage or by an outside stimulus.<ref name="BlaiszikKramer2010">{{cite journal|last1=Blaiszik|first1=B.J.|last2=Kramer|first2=S.L.B.|last3=Olugebefola|first3=S.C.|last4=Moore|first4=J.S.|last5=Sottos|first5=N.R.|last6=White|first6=S.R.|title=Self-Healing Polymers and Composites|journal=Annual Review of Materials Research|volume=40|issue=1|year=2010|pages=179–211|issn=1531-7331|doi=10.1146/annurev-matsci-070909-104532|bibcode=2010AnRMS..40..179B}}</ref> Extrinsic self-healing materials can achieve healing efficiencies over 100% even when the damage is large.<ref>{{Cite journal | last = Wang | first = Yongjing | last2 = Pham | first2 = Duc Truong | last3 = Ji | first3 = Chunqian | date = 2015-12-31 | title = Self-healing composites: A review | journal = Cogent Engineering | volume = 2 | issue = 1 | pages = 1075686 | doi = 10.1080/23311916.2015.1075686 }}</ref>
====Microcapsule healing==== Capsule-based systems have in common that healing agents are encapsulated into suitable microstructures that rupture upon crack formation and lead to a follow up process in order to restore the materials' properties. If the walls of the capsule are created too thick, they may not fracture when the crack approaches, but if they are too thin, they may rupture prematurely.<ref name="White2001"/> In order for this process to happen at room [[temperature]], and for the reactants to remain in a monomeric state within the capsule, a [[catalyst]] is also imbedded into the thermoset. The catalyst lowers the [[energy barrier]] of the [[Chemical reaction|reaction]] and allows the monomer to polymerize without the addition of heat. The capsules (often made of [[wax]]) around the monomer and the catalyst are important to maintain separation until the crack facilitates the reaction.<ref name=mendablepolymers /><ref name=Solventpromotedselfhealing /> In the capsule-catalyst system, the encapsulated healing agent is released into the polymer matrix and reacts with the catalyst, already present in the matrix.<ref name="Brown2002"/> There are many challenges in designing this type of material. First, the reactivity of the [[catalyst]] must be maintained even after it is enclosed in wax. Additionally, the monomer must flow at a sufficient rate (have low enough [[viscosity]]) to cover the entire crack before it is polymerized, or full healing capacity will not be reached. Finally, the catalyst must quickly dissolve into the monomer in order to react efficiently and prevent the crack from spreading further.<ref name=Solventpromotedselfhealing>{{cite journal|title = Solvent-Promoted Self-Healing in Epoxy Materials|journal = Macromolecules|year = 2007|volume =40|pages =8830–8832|doi = 10.1021/ma701992z|author = White, S. R.|last2 = Delafuente|first2 = David A.|last3 = Ho|first3 = Victor|last4 = Sottos|first4 = Nancy R.|last5 = Moore|first5 = Jeffrey S.|last6 = White|first6 = Scott R.|issue = 25|bibcode = 2007MaMol..40.8830C |citeseerx = 10.1.1.494.785}}</ref>
[[File:Dicyclpentadiene ring-opening polymerization.png| thumb|300 px|'''Scheme 6.''' ROMP of DCPD via [[Grubbs' catalyst]]]]
This process has been demonstrated with [[dicyclopentadiene]] (DCPD) and [[Grubbs' catalyst]] (benzylidene-bis(tricyclohexylphosphine)dichlororuthenium). Both DCPD and [[Grubbs' catalyst]] are imbedded in an [[epoxy]] [[resin]]. The [[monomer]] on its own is relatively unreactive and [[polymerization]] does not take place. When a microcrack reaches both the capsule containing DCPD and the [[catalyst]], the [[monomer]] is released from the core–shell microcapsule and comes in contact with exposed catalyst, upon which the monomer undergoes [[ring opening metathesis polymerization]] (ROMP).<ref name=Solventpromotedselfhealing /> The [[Metathesis reaction|metathesis]] reaction of the [[monomer]] involves the severance of the two double bonds in favor of new bonds. The presence of the [[catalyst]] allows for the [[energy barrier]] (energy of activation) to be lowered, and the polymerization [[Chemical reaction|reaction]] can proceed at room temperature.<ref name=grubbs>{{cite journal|title = Polymerization and Organotransition Metal Chemistry|journal = Science|year = 1989|volume =243|pages =907–915|author = Grubbs, R.|doi = 10.1126/science.2645643|pmid = 2645643|last2 = Tumas|first2 = W|issue = 4893|bibcode = 1989Sci...243..907G }}</ref> The resulting [[polymer]] allows the [[epoxy]] [[composite material]] to regain 67% of its former strength.
[[Grubbs' catalyst]] is a good choice for this type of system because it is insensitive to air and water, thus robust enough to maintain reactivity within the material. Using a live catalyst is important to promote multiple healing actions.<ref name=pangbond /> The major drawback is the cost. It was shown that using more of the catalyst corresponded directly to higher degree of healing. [[Ruthenium]] is quite costly, which makes it impractical for commercial applications.
[[File:polymerization in situ.jpg|thumb|600 px| center|'''Figure 1.''' Depiction of crack propagation through microcapsule-imbedded material. Monomer microcapsules are represented by pink circles and catalyst is shown by purple dots.]]
In contrast, in multicapsule systems both the catalyst and the healing agent are encapsulated in different capsules.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Keller|first1=M.W.|last2=White|first2=S.R.|last3=Sottos|first3=N.R.|title=A self-healing poly(dimethyl siloxane) elastomer|journal=Adv. Funct. Mater.|date=2007|volume=17|issue=14|pages=2399–404|doi=10.1002/adfm.200700086}}</ref> In a third system, called latent functionality, a healing agent is encapsulated, that can react with the polymerizer component that is present in the matrix in the form of residual reactive functionalities.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Caruso|first1=M.M|last2=Delafuente|first2=D.A.|last3=Ho|first3=V.|last4=Sottos|first4=N.R.|last5=Moore|first5=J.S.|last6=White|first6=S.R.|title=Solvent-Promoted Self-Healing Epoxy Materials|journal=Macromolecules|date=2007|volume=40|issue=25|pages=8830–32|doi=10.1021/ma701992z|bibcode=2007MaMol..40.8830C|citeseerx=10.1.1.494.785}}</ref> In the last approach (phase separation), either the healing agent or the polymerizer is phase-separated in the matrix material.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Cho|first1=S.H.|last2=Andersson|first2=H.M.|last3=White|first3=S.R.|last4=Sottos|first4=N.R.|last5=Braun|first5=P.V.|title=Polydimethylsiloxane-Based Self-Healing Materials|journal=Adv. Mater.|date=2006|volume=18|issue=8|pages=997–1000|doi=10.1002/adma.200501814}}</ref>
====Vascular approaches==== The same strategies can be applied in 1D, 2D and 3D vascular based systems.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Dry|first1=C.M.|last2=Sottos|first2=N.R.|title=Passive smart self-repair in polymer matrix composite materials|journal=Smart Structures and Materials 1993: Smart Materials|date=1993|volume=SPIE Proc.|issue=1916|pages=438–44|doi=10.1117/12.148501|bibcode=1993SPIE.1916..438D}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Wang|first1=K.M.|last2=Lorente|first2=S.|last3=Bejan|first3=A.|title=Vascularized networks with two optimized channel sizes|journal=J. Phys. D: Appl. Phys.|date=2006|volume=39|issue=14|pages=3086–96|doi=10.1088/0022-3727/39/14/031|bibcode=2006JPhD...39.3086W}}</ref><ref name="Toohey, K.S. 2007"/>
====Hollow tube approach==== For the first method, fragile glass capillaries or fibers are imbedded within a [[composite material]]. (Note: this is already a commonly used practice for strengthening materials. See [[Fiber-reinforced plastic]].)<ref name=cdry>{{cite journal|title = Procedures Developed for Self-Repair of Polymer Matrix Composite Materials|journal = Composite Structure|year = 1996|volume =35|pages =263–264|author = Dry, C.|doi = 10.1016/0263-8223(96)00033-5|issue = 3}}</ref> The resulting porous network is filled with [[monomer]]. When damage occurs in the material from regular use, the tubes also crack and the monomer is released into the cracks. Other tubes containing a hardening agent also crack and mix with the [[monomer]], causing the crack to be healed.<ref name=pangbond>{{cite journal|title = A Hollow Fibre Reinforced Polymer Composite Encompassing Self-Healing and Enhanced Damage Visibility|journal = Composite Science and Technology|year = 2005|volume =65|pages =1791–1799|doi = 10.1016/j.compscitech.2005.03.008 |author1=Pang, J. W. C. |author2=Bond, I. P. |issue = 11–12|citeseerx = 10.1.1.552.4996}}</ref> There are many things to take into account when introducing hollow tubes into a [[crystalline structure]]. First to consider is that the created channels may compromise the load bearing ability of the material due to the removal of load bearing material.<ref name="OlugebefolaAragon2010">{{cite journal|last1=Olugebefola|first1=S. C.|last2=Aragon|first2=A. M.|last3=Hansen|first3=C. J.|last4=Hamilton|first4=A. R.|last5=Kozola|first5=B. D.|last6=Wu|first6=W.|last7=Geubelle|first7=P. H.|last8=Lewis|first8=J. A.|last9=Sottos|first9=N. R.|last10=White|first10=S. R.|title=Polymer Microvascular Network Composites|journal=Journal of Composite Materials|volume=44|issue=22|year=2010|pages=2587–2603|issn=0021-9983|doi=10.1177/0021998310371537|bibcode = 2010JCoMa..44.2587O |display-authors=8}}</ref> Also, the channel diameter, degree of branching, location of branch points, and channel orientation are some of the main things to consider when building up microchannels within a material. Materials that don’t need to withstand much mechanical [[Deformation (mechanics)|strain]], but want self-healing properties, can introduce more microchannels than materials that are meant to be load bearing.<ref name="OlugebefolaAragon2010"/> There are two types of hollow tubes: discrete channels, and interconnected channels.<ref name="OlugebefolaAragon2010"/>
=====Discrete channels===== Discrete channels can be built independently of building the material and are placed in an array throughout the material.<ref name="OlugebefolaAragon2010"/> When creating these microchannels, one major factor to take into account is that the closer the tubes are together, the lower the strength will be, but the more efficient the recovery will be.<ref name="OlugebefolaAragon2010"/> A sandwich structure is a type of discrete channels that consists of tubes in the center of the material, and heals outwards from the middle.<ref name="WilliamsTrask2007">{{cite journal|last1=Williams|first1=H R|last2=Trask|first2=R S|last3=Bond|first3=I P|title=Self-healing composite sandwich structures|journal=Smart Materials and Structures|volume=16|issue=4|year=2007|pages=1198–1207|issn=0964-1726|doi=10.1088/0964-1726/16/4/031|bibcode = 2007SMaS...16.1198W }}</ref> The stiffness of sandwich structures is high, making it an attractive option for [[pressurized]] chambers.<ref name="WilliamsTrask2007"/> For the most part in sandwich structures, the strength of the material is maintained as compared to vascular networks. Also, material shows almost full recovery from damage.<ref name="WilliamsTrask2007"/>
=====Interconnected networks===== Interconnected networks are more [[efficiency|efficient]] than discrete channels, but are harder and more expensive to create.<ref name="OlugebefolaAragon2010"/> The most basic way to create these channels is to apply basic machining principles to create micro scale channel grooves. These techniques yield channels from 600–700 micrometers.<ref name="OlugebefolaAragon2010"/> This technique works great on the two-dimensional plane, but when trying to create a three-dimensional network, they are limited.<ref name="OlugebefolaAragon2010"/>
=====Direct ink writing===== The Direct Ink Writing (DIW) technique is a controlled extrusion of viscoelastic inks to create three-dimensional [[interconnected]] networks.<ref name="OlugebefolaAragon2010"/> It works by first setting [[Organic compound|organic]] ink in a defined pattern. Then the structure is infiltrated with a material like an [[epoxy]]. This epoxy is then [[solidified]], and the ink can be sucked out with a modest vacuum, creating the hollow tubes.<ref name="OlugebefolaAragon2010"/>
=====Carbon nanotube networks===== Through dissolving a linear [[polymer]] inside a solid three-dimensional [[epoxy]] matrix, so that they are miscible to each other, the linear polymer becomes mobile at a certain [[temperature]]<ref name="HayesJones2007">{{cite journal|last1=Hayes|first1=S.A.|last2=Jones|first2=F.R.|last3=Marshiya|first3=K.|last4=Zhang|first4=W.|title=A self-healing thermosetting composite material|journal=Composites Part A: Applied Science and Manufacturing|volume=38|issue=4|year=2007|pages=1116–1120|issn=1359-835X|doi=10.1016/j.compositesa.2006.06.008}}</ref> When [[carbon nanotube]]s are also incorporated into epoxy material, and a [[direct current]] is run through the tubes, a significant shift in sensing curve indicates permanent damage to the [[polymer]], thus ‘sensing’ a crack.<ref name="ThostensonChou2006">{{cite journal|last1=Thostenson|first1=E. T.|last2=Chou|first2=T.-W.|title=Carbon Nanotube Networks: Sensing of Distributed Strain and Damage for Life Prediction and Self Healing|journal=Advanced Materials|volume=18|issue=21|year=2006|pages=2837–2841|issn=0935-9648|doi=10.1002/adma.200600977}}</ref> When the [[carbon nanotube]]s sense a crack within the [[structure]], they can be used as thermal transports to heat up the matrix so the linear [[polymer]]s can diffuse to fill the cracks in the epoxy matrix. Thus healing the material.<ref name="HayesJones2007"/>
=====SLIPS===== A different approach was suggested by Prof. J. Aizenberg from Harvard University, who suggested to use [[Slippery Liquid-Infused Porous Surfaces]] (SLIPS), a porous material inspired by the carnivorous pitcher plant and filled with a lubricating liquid immiscible with both water and oil.<ref name="aizenberg2011">{{cite journal|last=Nosonovsky|first=M.|title=Materials science: Slippery when wetted|journal=Nature|volume=477|issue=7365|year=2011|pages=412–413|doi=10.1038/477412a|pmid=21938059|bibcode = 2011Natur.477..412N }}</ref> SLIPS possess self-healing and self-lubricating properties as well as icephobicity and were successfully used for many purposes.
=====Sacrificial thread stitching===== Organic threads (such as polylactide filament for example) are stitched through laminate layers of fiber reinforced polymer, which are then boiled and vacuumed out of the material after curing of the polymer, leaving behind empty channels than can be filled with healing agents.<ref name="Beckman">{{cite web|title=Repeated Self-Healing Now Possible in Composite Materials|url=http://beckman.illinois.edu/news/2014/04/self-healing-composites|website=Beckman Institute|accessdate=17 November 2016}}</ref>
==Self-healing fibre-reinforced polymer composites== Methods for the implementation of self-healing functionality into filled composites and fibre reinforced polymers (FRPs) are almost exclusively based on extrinsic systems and thus can be broadly classified into two approaches; discrete capsule-based systems and continuous vascular systems. In contrast to non-filled polymers, the success of an intrinsic approach based on bond reversibility has yet to be proven in FRPs. To date, self-healing of FRPs has mostly been applied to simple structures such as flat plates and panels. There is however a somewhat limited application of self-healing in flat panels, as access to the panel surface is relatively simple and repair methods are very well established in industry. Instead, there has been a strong focus on implementing self-healing in more complex and industrially relevant structures such as T-Joints<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Yang | first1 = T. | last2 = Zhang | first2 = J. | last3 = Mouritz | first3 = A. P. | last4 = Wang | first4 = C. H. | year = 2013 | title = Healing of carbon fibre–epoxy composite T-joints using mendable polymer fibre stitching | journal = Composites Part B: Engineering | volume = 45 | pages = 1499–1507 | doi=10.1016/j.compositesb.2012.08.022}}</ref><ref>Cullinan, J. F., Wisnom, M., and Bond, I., "A Novel Method for the Manipulation of Damage and In-Situ Repair of Composite T-Joints," 56th AIAA/ASCE/AHS/ASC Structures, Structural Dynamics, and Materials Conference, Reston, Virginia: American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, 2015, pp. 1–10</ref> and Aircraft Fuselages.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Minakuchi | first1 = S. | last2 = Sun | first2 = D. | last3 = Takeda | first3 = N. | year = 2014 | title = Hierarchical system for autonomous sensing-healing of delamination in large-scale composite structures | journal = Smart Materials and Structures | volume = 23 | issue = 11| page = 115014 | doi=10.1088/0964-1726/23/11/115014| bibcode = 2014SMaS...23k5014M }}</ref>
===Capsule-based systems=== The creation of a capsule-based system was first reported by White et al. in 2001,<ref name="White2001"/> and this approach has since been adapted by a number of authors for introduction into fibre reinforced materials.<ref name="KW2001">{{cite journal|last1=Kessler|first1= M. R. |last2=White|first2=S. R.|url=http://autonomic.beckman.illinois.edu/files/MikeKessler.pdf|title=Self-activated healing of delamination damage in woven composites|journal=Composites Part A: Applied Science and Manufacturing|date=2001|volume=32|issue= 5 |pages=683–699|doi=10.1016/s1359-835x(00)00149-4}}</ref><ref name="KSW2003"/><ref name="Patel">{{cite journal|last1=Patel|first1= A. J. |last2=Sottos|first2=N. R.|last3=Wetzel|first3=E. D.|last4=White|first4=S. R.|title=Autonomic healing of low-velocity impact damage in fibre-reinforced composites|journal=Composites Part A: Applied Science and Manufacturing|date=2010|volume=41|issue= 3 |pages=360–368|doi=10.1016/j.compositesa.2009.11.002}}</ref> This method relies on the release of an encapsulated healing agent into the damage zone, and is generally a once off process as the functionality of the encapsulated healing agent cannot be restored. Even so, implemented systems are able to restore material integrity to almost 100% and remain stable over the material lifetime.
===Vascular systems=== A vascular or fibre-based approach may be more appropriate for self-healing impact damage in fibre-reinforced polymer composite materials. In this method, a network of hollow channels known as vascules, similar to the blood vessels within human tissue, are placed within the structure and used for the introduction of a healing agent. During a damage event cracks propagate through the material and into the vascules causing them to be cleaved open. A liquid resin is then passed through the vascules and into the damage plane, allowing the cracks to be repaired. Vascular systems have a number of advantages over microcapsule based systems, such as the ability to continuously deliver large volumes of repair agents and the potential to be used for repeated healing. The hollow channels themselves can also be used for additional functionality, such as thermal management and structural health monitoring.<ref name="Norris">{{cite journal | last1 = Norris | first1 = C. J. | last2 = White | first2 = J. A. P. | last3 = McCombe | first3 = G. | last4 = Chatterjee | first4 = P. | last5 = Bond | first5 = I. P. | last6 = Trask | first6 = R. S. | year = 2012 | title = Autonomous stimulus triggered self-healing in smart structural composites | journal = Smart Materials and Structures | volume = 21 | issue = 9| page = 094027 | doi=10.1088/0964-1726/21/9/094027| bibcode = 2012SMaS...21i4027N }}</ref> A number of methods have been proposed for the introduction of these vascules, including the use of hollow glass fibres (HGFs),<ref name="Bleay">{{cite journal|last1=Bleay|first1= S. |last2=Loader|first2=C.|last3=Hawyes|first3=V.|last4=Humberstone|first4=L.|last5=Curtis|first5=P.|title=A smart repair system for polymer matrix composites|journal=Composites Part A: Applied Science and Manufacturing|date=2001|volume=32|issue= 12 |pages=1767–1776|doi=10.1016/s1359-835x(01)00020-3}}</ref> <ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Trask | first1 = R.S. | last2 = Bond | first2 = I.P. | year = 2006 | title = Biomimetic self-healing of advanced composite structures using hollow glass fibres | journal = Smart Materials and Structures | volume = 15 | issue = 3| pages = 704–10 | doi=10.1088/0964-1726/15/3/005| bibcode = 2006SMaS...15..704T }}</ref> 3D printing,<ref name="Toohey, K.S. 2007"/> a ‘lost wax’ process <ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Trask | first1 = R. S. | last2 = Bond | first2 = I. P. | year = 2010 | title = Bioinspired engineering study of Plantae vascules for self-healing composite structures | journal = Journal of the Royal Society, Interface | volume = 7 | issue = 47| pages = 921–31 | doi=10.1098/rsif.2009.0420| pmid = 19955122 | pmc = 2871803 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Esser-Kahn | first1 = A.P. | last2 = Thakre | first2 = P.R. | last3 = Dong | first3 = H. | last4 = Patrick | first4 = J.F. | last5 = Vlasko-Vlasov | first5 = V.K. | last6 = Sottos | first6 = N.R. | display-authors = 6 | last7 = et al | year = 2011 | title = Three-dimensional microvascular fiber-reinforced composites | journal = Advanced Materials | volume = 23 | issue = 32| pages = 3654–8 | doi=10.1002/adma.201100933| pmid = 21766345 }}</ref> and a solid preform route.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Huang | first1 = C-Y. | last2 = Trask | first2 = R.S. | last3 = Bond | first3 = I.P. | year = 2010 | title = Characterization and analysis of carbon fibre-reinforced polymer composite laminates with embedded circular vasculature | journal = Journal of the Royal Society, Interface | volume = 7 | issue = 49| pages = 1229–41 | doi=10.1098/rsif.2009.0534| pmid = 20150337 | pmc = 2894872 }}</ref>
==Self-healing coatings== Coatings allow the retention and improvement of bulk properties of a material. They can provide protection for a substrate from environmental exposure. Thus, when damage occurs (often in the form of microcracks), environmental elements like water and oxygen can diffuse through the coating and may cause material damage or failure. Microcracking in coatings can result in mechanical degradation or delamination of the coating, or in electrical failure in fibre-reinforced composites and microelectronics, respectively. As the damage is on such a small scale, repair, if possible, is often difficult and costly. Therefore, a coating that can automatically heal itself (“self-healing coating”) could prove beneficial by automatic recovering properties (such as mechanical, electrical and aesthetic properties), and thus extending the lifetime of the coating. The majority of the approaches that are described in literature regarding self-healing materials can be applied to make “self-healing” coatings, including microencapsulation<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Aissa | first1 = B. | last2 = Therriault | first2 = D. | last3 = Haddad | first3 = E. | last4 = Jamroz | first4 = W. | year = 2011 | title = Self-Healing Materials Systems: Overview of Major Approaches and Recent Developed Technologies | journal = Advances in Materials Science and Engineering | volume = 2012 | pages = 1–17 | doi = 10.1155/2012/854203 }}</ref><ref name="White2001">{{cite journal|last1=White|first1=S. R.|last2=Sottos|first2=N. R.|last3=Geubelle|first3=P. H.|last4=Moore|first4=J. S.|last5=Kessler|first5=M. R.|last6=Sriram|first6=S. R.|last7=Brown|first7=E. N.|last8=Viswanathan|first8=S.|title=Autonomic healing of polymer composites|journal=Nature|date=15 February 2001|volume=409|issue=6822|pages=794–797|doi=10.1038/35057232|pmid=11236987}}</ref> and the introduction of reversible physical bonds such as hydrogen bonding,<ref name="Chen2014"/> ionomers <ref name="Binder">{{cite book|last1=Binder|first1=Wolfgang H.|title=Self-healing polymers : from principles to applications|date=2013|publisher=Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH|location=Weinheim|isbn=978-3-527-33439-1|edition=1|pages=315–334|doi=10.1002/9783527670185.ch13|chapter=Self-Healing Ionomers}}</ref><ref name="Varley">{{cite journal|last1=Varley, R.J., Zwaag, S.V.D|title=Development of a quasi-static test method to investigate the origin of self-healing in ionomers under ballistic conditions|journal=Polymer Testing|date=2008|volume=27|pages=11–19|doi=10.1016/j.polymertesting.2007.07.013}}</ref> and chemical bonds (Diels-Alder chemistry).<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Liua, Y.L., Chuoa, T.W|title=Self-healing polymers based on thermally reversible Diels–Alder chemistry|journal=Polymer Chemistry|date=2013|volume=4|issue=7|pages=2194–2205|doi=10.1039/C2PY20957H}}</ref> Microencapsulation is the most common method to develop self-healing coatings. The capsule approach originally described by White et al., using microencapsulated dicyclopentadiene (DCPD) monomer and Grubbs’ catalyst to self-heal epoxy polymer<ref name="White2001"/> was later adapted to epoxy adhesive films that are commonly used in the aerospace and automotive industries for bonding metallic and composite substrates.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Jin, H.|title=Fracture behavior of a self-healing, toughened epoxy adhesive|journal=Int. J. Adhes. Adhes.|date=2013|volume=44|pages=157–165|doi=10.1016/j.ijadhadh.2013.02.015|display-authors=etal}}</ref> Recently, microencapsulated liquid suspensions of metal or carbon black were used to restore electrical conductivity in a multilayer microelectronic device and battery electrodes respectively;<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Blaiszik, B.J.|title=Autonomic restoration of electrical conductivity|journal=Adv. Mater.|date=2011|volume=24|issue=3|pages=398–401|doi=10.1002/adma.201102888|pmid=22183927|display-authors=etal}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Kang, S.|title=Microencapsulated carbon black suspensions for restoration of electrical conductivity|journal=Adv. Funct. Mater.|date=2014|volume=24|issue=20|pages=2947–2956|doi=10.1002/adfm.201303427|display-authors=etal}}</ref> however the use of microencapsulation for restoration of electrical properties in coatings is limited. Liquid metal microdroplets have also been suspended within silicone elastomer to create stretchable electrical conductors that maintain electrical conductivity when damaged, mimicking the resilience of soft biological tissue.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Markvicka|first=Eric J.|last2=Bartlett|first2=Michael D.|last3=Huang|first3=Xiaonan|last4=Majidi|first4=Carmel|date=2018-05-21|title=An autonomously electrically self-healing liquid metal–elastomer composite for robust soft-matter robotics and electronics|url=http://www.nature.com/articles/s41563-018-0084-7|journal=Nature Materials|volume=17|issue=7|pages=618–624|language=En|doi=10.1038/s41563-018-0084-7|pmid=29784995|issn=1476-1122|bibcode=2018NatMa..17..618M}}</ref> The most common application of this technique is proven in polymer coatings for corrosion protection. Corrosion protection of metallic materials is of significant importance on an economical and ecological scale. To prove the effectiveness of microcapsules in polymer coatings for corrosion protection, researchers have encapsulated a number of materials. These materials include isocyanates<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Huang, M. and Yang, J|title=Facile microencapsulation of HDI for self-healing anticorrosion coatings|journal=Journal of Materials Chemistry|date=2011|volume=21|issue=30|pages=11123–11130|doi=10.1039/C1JM10794A}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Yang, J., Keller, M.W., Moore, J.F., White, S.R., Sottos, N.R|title=Microencapsulation of Isocyanates for Self-Healing Polymers|journal=Macromolecules|date=2008|volume=41|issue=24|pages=9650–9655|doi=10.1021/ma801718v|bibcode=2008MaMol..41.9650Y}}</ref> monomers such as DCPD<ref name="Brown2002">{{cite journal|last1=Brown, E. N., Sottos, N. R. and White, S. R|title=Fracture testing of a self-healing polymer composite|journal=Experimental Mechanics|date=2002|volume=42|issue=4|pages=372–379|doi=10.1007/BF02412141|hdl=2142/265}}</ref><ref name="KSW2003">{{cite journal|last1=Kessler|first1= M. R. |last2=Sottos|first2=N. R.|last3=White|first3=S. R.|title=Self-healing structural composite materials|journal=Composites Part A: Applied Science and Manufacturing|date=2003|volume=34|issue=8|pages=743–753|doi=10.1016/S1359-835X(03)00138-6}}</ref> GMA<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Meng, L.M., Yuan, Y.C., Rong, M.Z. and Zhang, M.Q|title=A dual mechanism single-component self-healing strategy for polymers|journal=Journal of Materials Chemistry|date=2010|volume=20|issue=29|pages=5969–6196|doi=10.1039/C0JM00268B}}</ref> epoxy resin,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Jin, H.H., Mangun, C.L., Stradley, D.S., Moore, J.S., Sottos, N.R., White, S.R|title=Self-healing thermoset using encapsulated epoxy-amine healing chemistry|journal=Polymer|date=2012|volume=53|issue=2|pages=581–587|doi=10.1016/j.polymer.2011.12.005}}</ref> linseed oil<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Suryanarayana, C., Rao, K.C. and Kumar, D|title=Preparation and characterization of microcapsules containing linseed oil and its use in self-healing coatings|journal=Progress in Organic Coatings|date=2008|volume=63|pages=72–78|doi=10.1016/j.porgcoat.2008.04.008}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Jadhav, R.S., Hundiwale, D.G. and Mahulikar, P.P|title=Synthesis and Characterization of Phenol–Formaldehyde Microcapsules Containing Linseed Oil and Its Use in Epoxy for Self-Healing and Anticorrosive Coating|journal=Journal of Applied Polymer Science|date=2011|volume=119|issue=5|pages=2911–2916|doi=10.1002/app.33010}}</ref> and tung oil.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Samadzadeha, M., Bouraa, S.H., Peikaria, M., Ashrafib, A. and Kasirihac, M|title=Tung oil: An autonomous repairing agent for self-healing epoxy coatings|journal=Progress in Organic Coatings|date=2011|volume=70|issue=4|pages=383–387|doi=10.1016/j.porgcoat.2010.08.017}}</ref> By using the aforementioned materials for self healing in coatings, it was proven that microencapsulation effectively protects the metal against corrosion and extends the lifetime of a coating.
==Self-healing cementitious materials== Cementitious materials have existed since the Roman era. These materials have a natural ability to self-heal, which was first reported by the French Academy of Science in 1836.<ref name="State of the art report">{{cite book|last1=de Rooij|first1=M|last2=Van Tittelboom|first2=K|last3=De Belie|first3=N|last4=Schlangen|first4=E|title=Self-Healing Phenomena in Cement-Based Materials|date=2011|publisher=Springer Netherlands|isbn=978-94-007-6624-2|url=https://www.springer.com/gp/book/9789400766235}}</ref> This ability can be improved by the integration of chemical and biochemical strategies.
===Autogenous healing=== Autogenous healing is the natural ability of cementitious materials to repair cracks. This ability is principally attributed to further hydration of unhydrated cement particles and carbonation of dissolved calcium hydroxide.<ref name="State of the art report"/> Cementitious materials in fresh-water systems can autogenously heal cracks up to 0.2 mm over a period of 7 weeks.<ref name=Carola>{{cite journal|last1=Edvardsen|first1=C|title=Water permeability and autogenous healing of cracks in concrete|journal=ACI Materials Journal|date=1999|volume=96|issue=4|pages=448–454|doi=10.14359/645|url=http://www.concrete.org/publications/acimaterialsjournal/acijournalsearch.aspx?m=details&ID=645}}</ref>
===Chemical additives based healing=== Self-healing of cementitious materials can be achieved through the reaction of certain chemical agents. Two main strategies exist for housing these agents, namely capsules and vascular tubes. These capsules and vascular tubes, once ruptured, release these agents and heal the crack damage. Studies have mainly focused on improving the quality of these housings and encapsulated materials in this field.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Mostavi|first1=Ehsan|last2=Asadi|first2=Somayeh|last3=Hassan|first3=Marwa|last4=Alansari|first4=Mohamed|title=Evaluation of Self-Healing Mechanisms in Concrete with Double-Walled Sodium Silicate Microcapsules|journal=Materials in Civil Engineering|volume=27|issue=12|pages=04015035|date=December 2015|doi=10.1061/(ASCE)MT.1943-5533.0001314|url=http://qufaculty.qu.edu.qa/m-alansari/wp-content/uploads/sites/109/2016/03/ASCE-Al-Ansari-Paper.pdf}}</ref>
===Bio-based healing=== The self-healing ability of concrete has been improved by the incorporation of bacteria, which can induce calcium carbonate precipitation through their metabolic activity.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Ehrlich|first1=H.L.|title=How microbes influence mineral growth and dissolution|journal=Chemical Geology|date=1996|volume=1–4|issue=132|pages=5–9|doi=10.1016/S0009-2541(96)00035-6|bibcode=1996ChGeo.132....5E}}</ref> These precipitates can build up and form an effective seal against crack related water ingress. Jonkers et al. first incorporated bacteria within cement paste for the development of self-healing concrete.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Jonkers|first1=H|last2=Thijssen|first2=A|last3=Muyzer|first3=G|last4=Copuroglu|first4=O|last5=Schlangen|first5=E|title=Application of bacteria as self-healing agent for the development of sustainable concrete|journal=Ecological Engineering|date=2010|volume=36|issue=2|pages=230–235|doi=10.1016/j.ecoleng.2008.12.036}}</ref> It was found that the bacteria directly added to the paste only remained viable for 4 months. Later studies saw Jonkers use expanded clay particles<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Jonkers|first1=H|title=Bacteria-based self-healing concrete|journal=HERON|date=2011|volume=56|issue=1/2|url=http://heronjournal.nl/56-12/1.pdf}}</ref> and Van Tittlelboom use glass tubes,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Van Tittelboom|first1=K|last2=De Belie|first2=N|last3=Van Loo|first3=D|last4=Jacobs|first4=P|title=Self-healing efficiency of cementitious materials containing tubular capsules filled with healing agent|journal=Cement and Concrete Composites|date=2011|volume=33|issue=4|pages=497–505|doi=10.1016/j.cemconcomp.2011.01.004}}</ref> to protect the bacteria inside the concrete. Other strategies to protect the bacteria have also since been reported.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Wang|first1=J|last2=Van Tittelboom|first2=K|last3=De Belie|first3=N|last4=Verstraete|first4=W|title=Use of silica gel or polyurethane immobilized bacteria for self-healing concrete|journal=Construction and Building Materials|date=2012|volume=26|issue=1|pages=532–540|doi=10.1016/j.conbuildmat.2011.06.054}}</ref>
==Self-healing ceramics== Generally, ceramics are superior in strength to metals at high temperatures, however, they are brittle and sensitive to flaws, and this brings into question their integrity and reliability as structural materials.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Ono|first1=M|last2=Nakao|first2=W|last3=Takahashi|first3=K|last4=Nakatani|first4=M|last5=Ando|first5=K|title=A new methodology to guarantee the structural integrity of Al2O3/SiC composite using crack healing and a proof test|journal=Fatigue Fract. Eng. Mater. Struct.|date=2007|volume=30|issue=7|pages=599–607|doi=10.1111/j.1460-2695.2007.01132.x}}</ref> <chem>M_{\mathit n+1}AX_\mathit{n}</chem> phase ceramics, also known as [[MAX Phases]], can autonomously heal crack damage by an intrinsic healing mechanism. Micro cracks caused by wear or thermal stress are filled with oxides formed from the MAX phase constituents, commonly the A-element, during high temperature exposure to air.<ref name="Number 2">{{cite journal|last1=Yang|first1=H. J.|last2=Pei|first2=Y. T.|last3=Rao|first3=J. C.|last4=De Hosson|first4=J. T. M.|title=Self-healing performance of Ti<sub>2</sub>AlC ceramic|journal=Journal of Materials Chemistry|date=2012|volume=22|issue=17|pages=8304–8313|doi=10.1039/C2JM16123K}}</ref> Crack gap filling was first demonstrated for Ti<sub>3</sub>AlC<sub>2</sub> by oxidation at 1200 °C in air.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Song|first1=G.M.|last2=Pei|first2=Y.T.|last3=Sloof|first3=W.G.|last4=Li|first4=S.B.|last5=De Hosson|first5=J.Th.M.|last6=van der Zwaag|first6=S.|title=Oxidation-induced crack healing in Ti<sub>3</sub>AlC<sub>2</sub> ceramics|journal=Scripta Materialia|date=January 2008|volume=58|issue=1|pages=13–16|doi=10.1016/j.scriptamat.2007.09.006}}</ref> Ti<sub>2</sub>AlC and Cr<sub>2</sub>AlC have also demonstrated said ability, and more ternary carbides and nitrides are expected to be able to autonomously self-heal.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Shibo|first1=L.|last2=Guiming|first2=S.|last3=Kwakernaak|first3=K.|last4=Van der Zwaag|first4=S.|last5=Sloof|first5=W. G.|title=Multiple crack healing of a Ti<sub>2</sub>AlC ceramic|journal=Journal of the European Ceramic Society|date=2012|volume=32|issue=8|pages=1813–1820|doi=10.1016/j.jeurceramsoc.2012.01.017}}</ref> The process is repeatable up to the point of element depletion, distinguishing MAX phases from other self-healing materials that require external healing agents (extrinsic healing) for single crack gap filling. Depending on the filling-oxide, improvement of the initial properties such as local strength can be achieved.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Farle|first1=A.|last2=Kwarkernaak|first2=C.|last3=Van der Zwaag|first3=S.|last4=Sloof|first4=W. G.|title=A conceptual study into the potential of Mn+1AXn-phase ceramics for self-healing of crack damage|journal=Journal of the European Ceramic Society|date=2015|volume=35|pages=37–45|doi=10.1016/j.jeurceramsoc.2014.08.046}}</ref> On the other hand, mullite, alumina and zirconia do not have the ability to heal intrinsically, but could be endowed with self-healing capabilities by embedding second phase components into the matrix. Upon cracking, these particles are exposed to oxygen, and in the presence of heat, they react to form new materials which fill the crack gap under volume expansion.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Nakao|first1=W.|last2=K.|first2=Takahashi|last3=K.|first3=Ando|title=Self-Healing materials, Design, strategies and applications|publisher=Wiley-VCH Verkag GmbH & Co KGaA|isbn=978-3-527-31829-2|page=188|date=2009-01-20}}</ref> This concept has been proven using SiC to heal cracks in an Alumina matrix,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Nakao|first1=W.|last2=Abe|first2=S.|title=Enhancement of the self-healing ability in oxidation induced self-healing ceramic by modifying the healing agent|journal=Smart Materials & Structures|date=2012|volume=21|issue=2|pages=1–7|doi=10.1088/0964-1726/21/2/025002|bibcode=2012SMaS...21b5002N}}</ref> and further studies have investigated the high temperature strength,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Nakao|first1=W.|last2=Takahashi|first2=K.|last3=Ando|first3=K.|title=Threshold stress during crack healing treatment of structural ceramics having crack healing ability|journal=Material Letters|date=2007|volume=61|issue=13|pages=2711–2713|doi=10.1016/j.matlet.2006.04.122}}</ref> and the static and cyclic fatigue strength of the healed part.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Ando|first1=K.|last2=Kim|first2=B.-S.|last3=Chu|first3=M.-C.|last4=Saito|first4=S.|last5=Takahashi|first5=K.|title=Crack-healing and Mechanical Behaviour of Al2O3/Sic composites at elevated temperature|journal=Fatigue Fract. Eng. Mater. Struct.|date=2004|volume=27|issue=7|pages=533–541|doi=10.1111/j.1460-2695.2004.00785.x}}</ref> The strength and bonding between the matrix and the healing agent are of prime importance and thus govern the selection of the healing particles.
===Self-healing metals=== When exposed for long times to high temperatures and moderate stresses, metals exhibit premature and low-ductility creep fracture, arising from the formation and growth of cavities. Those defects coalesce into cracks which ultimately cause macroscopic failure. Self-healing of early stage damage is thus a promising new approach to extend the lifetime of the metallic components. In metals, self-healing is intrinsically more difficult to achieve than in most other material classes, due to their high melting point and, as a result, low atom mobility. Generally, defects in the metals are healed by the formation of precipitates at the defect sites that immobilize further crack growth. Improved creep and fatigue properties have been reported for underaged aluminium alloys compared to the peak hardening Al alloys, which is due to the heterogeneous precipitation at the crack tip and its plastic zone.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Lumley, R.N., A.J. Morton, and I.J. Polmear|title=Enhanced creep performance in an Al-Cu-Mg-Ag alloy through underageing|journal=Acta Materialia|date=2002|volume=50|issue=14|pages=3597–3608|doi=10.1016/S1359-6454(02)00164-7}}</ref> The first attempts to heal creep damage in steels were focused on the dynamic precipitation of either Cu or BN at the creep-cavity surface.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Laha, K.|title=Beneficial effect of B segregation on creep cavitation in a type 347 austenitic stainless steel|journal=Scripta Materialia|date=2005|volume=52|issue=7|pages=675–678|doi=10.1016/j.scriptamat.2004.11.016|display-authors=etal}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Laha, K., J. Kyono, and N. Shinya|title=An advanced creep cavitation resistance Cu-containing 18Cr-12Ni-Nb austenitic stainless steel|journal=Scripta Materialia|date=2007|volume=56|issue=10|pages=915–918|doi=10.1016/j.scriptamat.2006.12.030}}</ref> Cu precipitation has only a weak preference for deformation-induced defects as a large fraction of spherical Cu precipitates is simultaneously formed with the matrix.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=He, S.M.|title=Thermally activated precipitation at deformation-induced defects in Fe-Cu and Fe-Cu-B-N alloys studied by positron annihilation spectroscopy|journal=Physical Review|date=2010|volume=B 81|issue=9|pages=094103|doi=10.1103/PhysRevB.81.094103|display-authors=etal|bibcode=2010PhRvB..81i4103H|url=http://resolver.tudelft.nl/uuid:78bbe9b1-73a8-4776-aa19-f9b3f201fa82}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=He, S.M.|title=In situ determination of aging precipitation in deformed Fe-Cu and Fe-Cu-B-N alloys by time-resolved small-angle neutron scattering|journal=Physical Review|date=2010|volume=B 82|issue=17|pages=174111|display-authors=etal|doi=10.1103/PhysRevB.82.174111|bibcode=2010PhRvB..82q4111H|url=http://resolver.tudelft.nl/uuid:86a7ea51-af5a-40d2-aabf-28cf36840d89}}</ref> Recently, gold atoms were recognized as a highly efficient healing agents in Fe-based alloys. A defect-induced mechanism is indicated for the Au precipitation, i.e. the Au solute remains dissolved until defects are formed.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Zhang, S.|title=Defect-induced Au precipitation in Fe–Au and Fe–Au–B–N alloys studied by in situ small-angle neutron scattering|journal=Acta Materialia|date=2013|volume=61|issue=18|pages=7009–7019|doi=10.1016/j.actamat.2013.08.015|display-authors=etal}}</ref> Autonomous repair of high-temperature creep damage was reported by alloying with a small amount of Au. Healing agents selectively precipitate at the free surface of a creep cavity, resulting in pore filling. For the lower stress levels up to 80% filling of the creep cavities with Au precipitates is achieved<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Zhang, S.|title=Self Healing of Creep Damage by Gold Precipitation in Iron Alloys|journal=Advanced Engineering Materials|date=2015|pages=1–6|doi=10.1002/adem.201400511|volume=17|issue=5|display-authors=etal}}</ref> resulting in a substantial increase in creep life time. Work to translate the concept of creep damage healing in simple binary or ternary model systems to real multicomponent creep steels is ongoing.
== Self-healing organic dyes == Recently, a several classes of organic dyes are discovered that self-heal after [[Photodegradation|photo-degradation]] when doped in [[Poly(methyl methacrylate)|PMMA]] and other polymer matrices.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Embaye|first=Natnael B.|last2=Ramini|first2=Shiva K.|last3=Kuzyk|first3=Mark G.|date=2008-08-07|title=Mechanisms of reversible photodegradation in disperse orange 11 dye doped in PMMA polymer|journal=The Journal of Chemical Physics|language=en|volume=129|issue=5|pages=054504|doi=10.1063/1.2963502|pmid=18698911|issn=0021-9606|arxiv=0808.3346}}</ref> This is also knows as reversible [[Photodegradation|photo-degradation]]. It was shown that, unlike common process like molecular diffusion,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ramini|first=Shiva K.|last2=Dawson|first2=Nathan|last3=Kuzyk|first3=Mark G.|date=2011-10-01|title=Testing the diffusion hypothesis as a mechanism of self-healing in Disperse Orange 11 doped in poly(methyl methacrylate)|url=https://www.osapublishing.org/josab/abstract.cfm?uri=josab-28-10-2408|journal=JOSA B|language=EN|volume=28|issue=10|pages=2408–2412|doi=10.1364/JOSAB.28.002408|issn=1520-8540|arxiv=1106.2732}}</ref> the mechanism is caused by dye-polymer interaction.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ramini|first=Shiva K.|last2=Kuzyk|first2=Mark G.|date=2012-08-07|title=A self healing model based on polymer-mediated chromophore correlations|journal=The Journal of Chemical Physics|language=en|volume=137|issue=5|pages=054705|doi=10.1063/1.4739295|pmid=22894369|issn=0021-9606}}</ref>
==Further applications== Self-healing epoxies can be incorporated on to metals in order to prevent corrosion. A substrate metal showed major degradation and rust formation after 72 hours of exposure. But after being coated with the self-healing epoxy, there was no visible damage under SEM after 72 hours of same exposure.<ref name="YangWei2011">{{cite journal|last1=Yang|first1=Zhao|last2=Wei|first2=Zhang|last3=Le-ping|first3=Liao|last4=Hong-mei|first4=Wang|last5=Wu-jun|first5=Li|title=The self-healing composite anticorrosion coating|journal=Physics Procedia|volume=18|year=2011|pages=216–221|issn=1875-3892|doi=10.1016/j.phpro.2011.06.084|bibcode=2011PhPro..18..216Y}}</ref>
==Assessment of self-healing efficacy== Numerous methodologies for the assessment of self-healing capabilities have been developed for each material class (Table 1).
{| class="wikitable" |+ Table 1. Damaging methods for self-healing assessment of different classes of material. |- ! Material class !! Damage mechanism !! Healing |- | Polymers || Razor blade/scalpel cut; Tensile test with rupture; Ballistic impact || Autonomic healing supramolecular networks |- | Polymers || Razor blade/scalpel cut || Temperature triggered supramolecular networks |- | Fibre Reinforced Composite || Delamination BVID (Barely Visible Impact Damage) || Vascular self-healing; Microcapsule self-healing |- | Coatings || Microcutting with corrosion; Corrosion/erosion; Pull-out tests (adhesion); Microscratching || Molecular inter-diffusion (solvent); Encapsulated agent |- | Concrete || Crack initiation by bending compression || Activation of microencapsulated agent |- | Ceramic || Crack initiation by indentation || Temperature triggered oxidation reaction |- | Ceramic coating || Crack initiation by indentation || Temperature triggered oxidation reaction |- | Polyurethane foam coating || Puncturing with a spike || Reduction of the effective leakage area by negative strains pushing the walls of the fissure in the foam coatings to one another.<ref name="Rampf, M. 2012"/> |}
Hence, when self-healing is assessed, different parameters need to be considered: type of stimulus (if any), healing time, maximum amount of healing cycles the material can tolerate, and degree of recovery, all whilst considering the material's virgin properties.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Zhu M, Rong MZ, Zhang MQ|title=Self-healing polymeric materials towards non-structural recovery of functional properties|journal=Polymer International|date=2014|volume=63|issue=10|pages=741–1749|doi=10.1002/pi.4723}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Pacheco J, Šavija B, Schlangen E, Polder RB|title=Assessment of cracks in reinforced concrete by means of electrical resistance and image analysis|journal=Construction and Building Materials|date=2014|volume=65|pages=417–426|doi=10.1016/j.conbuildmat.2014.05.001}}</ref><ref name="Chen2014">{{cite journal|last1=Chen|first1=Yulin|last2=Guan|first2=Zhibin|title=Multivalent hydrogen bonding block copolymers self-assemble into strong and tough self-healing materials|journal=Chemical Communications|date=28 July 2014|volume=50|issue=74|pages=10868–10870|doi=10.1039/C4CC03168G|pmid=25090104}}</ref> This typically takes account of relevant physical parameters such as tensile modulus, elongation at break, fatigue-resistance, barrier properties, colour and transparency. The self-healing ability of a given material generally refers to the recovery of a specific property relative to the virgin material, designated as the self-healing efficiency. The self-healing efficiency can be quantified by comparing the respective experimental value obtained for the undamaged virgin sample (''f''<sub>virgin</sub>) with the healed sample (''f''<sub>healed</sub>) (eq. {{EquationNote|1}})<ref name="Mauldin">{{cite journal|last1=Mauldin|first1=T C|last2=Kessler|first2=M R|title=Self-healing polymers and composites|journal=International Materials Reviews|date=2010|volume=55|issue=6|pages=317–346|doi=10.1179/095066010X12646898728408}}</ref>
{{NumBlk|:|3={{EquationRef|1}}|2= ''η'' = {{sfrac|''f''<sub>healed</sub>|''f''<sub>virgin</sub>}}}}
In a variation of this definition that is relevant to extrinsic self-healing materials, the healing efficiency takes into consideration the modification of properties caused by introducing the healing agent. Accordingly, the healed sample property is compared to that of an undamaged control equipped with self-healing agent f<sub>non-healed</sub> (equation {{EquationNote|2}}).
{{NumBlk|:|3={{EquationRef|2}}|2= ''η'' = {{sfrac|''f''<sub>healed</sub>|''f''<sub>non-healed</sub>}}}}
For a certain property Pi of a specific material, an optimal self-healing mechanism and process is characterized by the full restoration of the respective material property after a suitable, normalized damaging process. For a material where 3 different properties are assessed, it should be determined 3 efficiencies given as ''ƞ''<sub>1</sub>(''P''<sub>1</sub>), ''ƞ''<sub>2</sub>(''P''<sub>2</sub>) and ''ƞ''<sub>3</sub>(''P''<sub>3</sub>). The final average efficiency based on a number n of properties for a self-healing material is accordingly determined as the harmonic mean given by equation {{EquationNote|3}}. The harmonic mean is more appropriate than the traditional arithmetic mean, as it is less sensitive to large outliers.
{{NumBlk|:|3={{EquationRef|3}}|2= <math>\bar{\eta} = \frac{n}{\sum_{i=1}^n \left (\frac{1}{\eta_i (P)}\right )}</math>}}
==Commercialization== At least two companies are attempting to bring the newer applications of self-healing materials to the market. [[Arkema]], a leading chemicals company, announced in 2009 the beginning of industrial production of self-healing elastomers.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Self-healing elastomer enters industrial production|url = http://www.arkema.com/en/media/news/news-details/Self-healing-elastomer-enters-industrial-production/|website = www.arkema.com|accessdate = 2015-12-13}}</ref> As of 2012, Autonomic Materials Inc., had raised over three million US dollars.<ref name="Bourzac">{{cite news|last1=Bourzac|first1=Katherine|title=First Self-Healing Coatings|url=http://www.technologyreview.com/business/21812/?a=f|accessdate=18 November 2016|work=technologyreview.com|date=December 12, 2008}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-19781862 |title= Time to heal: The materials that repair themselves |publisher= BBC |first= Paul |last=Rincon |date = 30 October 2010 |accessdate=19 May 2013}} </ref>
